title: Zombie (dNetHack)
data:
In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack") and [notdNetHack](/wiki/NotdNetHack "NotdNetHack"), most **[zombies](/wiki/Zombie "Zombie")** are a form of [derived undead](/wiki/Derived_undead "Derived undead") that occur throughout the dungeon rather than distinct monsters as in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*, and are generated by way of monster template.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)
- [2 Description](#Description)
- [3 Other zombies](#Other_zombies)
- [4 References](#References)

## Generation

Randomly generated zombies occur in groups. Living monsters that are damaged in melee by zombies (or damaged by any [skeletal](/index.php?title=Skeleton_\(dNetHack\)\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Skeleton (dNetHack) (page does not exist)") monster, with a 1⁄20 chance each hit) and then killed by any means that leaves behind their [corpse](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse") will rise from the dead as a zombie themselves. The presence of a [dread seraph](/wiki/Dread_seraph "Dread seraph") on a level will cause any corpses dropped to revive as zombies.

## Description

A zombified monster is [mindless](/wiki/Mindless "Mindless") and gains [cold resistance](/wiki/Cold_resistance "Cold resistance"), [poison resistance](/wiki/Poison_resistance "Poison resistance") and [sleep resistance](/wiki/Sleep_resistance "Sleep resistance"); they are resistant to piercing and bludgeoning weapons, they have a roughly 1⁄2 chance of reviving from their corpse, and their base dice for melee attacks are doubled (or tripled at [midnight](/wiki/Midnight "Midnight")). However, they have a 2-point penalty to [AC](/wiki/AC "AC") and take double damage from slashing weapons - weapons that have been given the "true death" boon by [the Silver Flame](/wiki/The_Silver_Flame "The Silver Flame") deal double damage + 2d7 additional damage.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1) They also tend to move slower than living monsters: a monster with a [speed](/wiki/Speed "Speed") of 6 or higher in their living form will have their speed in zombie form lowered to the higher of two values between half their normal speed and 6.

Other non-undead monsters will mutually [grudge](/wiki/Grudge "Grudge") zombies, with each attacking the other on sight.

## Other zombies

A basic ["zombie"](/wiki/Zombie_\(monster\)#dNetHack "Zombie (monster)") still exists in monst.c as a form of fallback for [wizard mode](/wiki/Wizard_mode "Wizard mode"), and is equivalent to the vanilla [human zombie](/wiki/Human_zombie "Human zombie") in this regard: [Guards](/wiki/Guard "Guard"), [high priests](/wiki/High_priest "High priest"), [aligned priests](/wiki/Aligned_priest "Aligned priest"), [shopkeepers](/wiki/Shopkeeper "Shopkeeper"), and [Angels](/wiki/Angel "Angel") are special-cased to become zombies if the player attempts to directly create them in [wizard mode](/wiki/Wizard_mode "Wizard mode"), as is the case for them in vanilla *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")* - these monsters are not intended to be created outside of specific circumstances.[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)

In addition to the above, dNetHack also has several distinct monsters in the [zombie](/wiki/Zombie_\(monster_class\) "Zombie (monster class)") [monster class](/wiki/Monster_class "Monster class"), most of them new:

- Z [undead knight](/index.php?title=Undead_knight\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Undead knight (page does not exist)")
- Z [warrior of sunlight](/index.php?title=Warrior_of_sunlight\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Warrior of sunlight (page does not exist)")
- Z [undead maiden](/index.php?title=Undead_maiden\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Undead maiden (page does not exist)")
- Z [knight of the princess's guard](/index.php?title=Knight_of_the_princess%27s_guard\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Knight of the princess's guard (page does not exist)")
- Z [blue sentinel](/index.php?title=Blue_sentinel\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Blue sentinel (page does not exist)")
- Z [darkmoon knight](/index.php?title=Darkmoon_knight\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Darkmoon knight (page does not exist)")
- Z [undead rebel](/index.php?title=Undead_rebel\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Undead rebel (page does not exist)")
- Z [pardoner](/index.php?title=Pardoner\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Pardoner (page does not exist)")
- Z [occultist](/index.php?title=Occultist\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Occultist (page does not exist)")
- Z [ghoul](/wiki/Ghoul "Ghoul")
- Z [hedrow zombie](/wiki/Hedrow_zombie "Hedrow zombie")
- Z [skeletal pirate](/wiki/Skeletal_pirate "Skeletal pirate")
- Z [hungry dead](/index.php?title=Hungry_dead\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Hungry dead (page does not exist)")
- Z [skeleton](/wiki/Skeleton "Skeleton")
- Z [gnoll ghoul](/wiki/Gnoll_ghoul "Gnoll ghoul")
- Z [dread seraph](/wiki/Dread_seraph "Dread seraph")
- Z [phalanx](/index.php?title=Phalanx\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Phalanx (page does not exist)")

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) Specifically, a bonus equal to double the sum of the base dice plus its enchantment, e.g. a +7 saber (1d8 base damage versus all monsters) would do 2x(1d8+7)+2d7.
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [src/read.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 2415](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/read.c#L2415): *In *NetHack*, this applies to animating their corpse or statue as well. While this technically also applies to shopkeepers, revival is special-cased to work on them.*

[![This article describes a 3.4.3-based variant of NetHack. Click here for more information.](/images/5/5d/Nh343var-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article describes a 3.4.3-based variant of NetHack. Click here for more information.")
html:
Zombie (dNetHack)

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search

In dNetHack and notdNetHack, most zombies are a form of derived undead that occur throughout the dungeon rather than distinct monsters as in NetHack, and are generated by way of monster template.

Contents

  • 1 Generation
  • 2 Description
  • 3 Other zombies
  • 4 References

Generation

Randomly generated zombies occur in groups. Living monsters that are damaged in melee by zombies (or damaged by any skeletal monster, with a 1⁄20 chance each hit) and then killed by any means that leaves behind their corpse will rise from the dead as a zombie themselves. The presence of a dread seraph on a level will cause any corpses dropped to revive as zombies.

Description

A zombified monster is mindless and gains cold resistance, poison resistance and sleep resistance; they are resistant to piercing and bludgeoning weapons, they have a roughly 1⁄2 chance of reviving from their corpse, and their base dice for melee attacks are doubled (or tripled at midnight). However, they have a 2-point penalty to AC and take double damage from slashing weapons - weapons that have been given the "true death" boon by the Silver Flame deal double damage + 2d7 additional damage.[1] They also tend to move slower than living monsters: a monster with a speed of 6 or higher in their living form will have their speed in zombie form lowered to the higher of two values between half their normal speed and 6.

Other non-undead monsters will mutually grudge zombies, with each attacking the other on sight.

Other zombies

A basic "zombie" still exists in monst.c as a form of fallback for wizard mode, and is equivalent to the vanilla human zombie in this regard: Guards, high priests, aligned priests, shopkeepers, and Angels are special-cased to become zombies if the player attempts to directly create them in wizard mode, as is the case for them in vanilla NetHack - these monsters are not intended to be created outside of specific circumstances.[2]

In addition to the above, dNetHack also has several distinct monsters in the zombie monster class, most of them new:

  • Z undead knight
  • Z warrior of sunlight
  • Z undead maiden
  • Z knight of the princess's guard
  • Z blue sentinel
  • Z darkmoon knight
  • Z undead rebel
  • Z pardoner
  • Z occultist
  • Z ghoul
  • Z hedrow zombie
  • Z skeletal pirate
  • Z hungry dead
  • Z skeleton
  • Z gnoll ghoul
  • Z dread seraph
  • Z phalanx

References

  1. ↑ Specifically, a bonus equal to double the sum of the base dice plus its enchantment, e.g. a +7 saber (1d8 base damage versus all monsters) would do 2x(1d8+7)+2d7.
  2. ↑ src/read.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 2415: In NetHack, this applies to animating their corpse or statue as well. While this technically also applies to shopkeepers, revival is special-cased to work on them.
Retrieved from "https://nethackwiki.com/index.php?title=Zombie_(dNetHack)&oldid=175188"

rawPage:
In [[dNetHack]] and [[notdNetHack]], most '''[[zombie]]s''' are a form of [[derived undead]] that occur throughout the dungeon rather than distinct monsters as in ''[[NetHack]]'', and are generated by way of monster template.

==Generation==
Randomly generated zombies occur in groups. Living monsters that are damaged in melee by zombies (or damaged by any [[Skeleton (dNetHack)|skeletal]] monster, with a {{frac|20}} chance each hit) and then killed by any means that leaves behind their [[corpse]] will rise from the dead as a zombie themselves. The presence of a [[dread seraph]] on a level will cause any corpses dropped to revive as zombies.

==Description==
A zombified monster is [[mindless]] and gains [[cold resistance]], [[poison resistance]] and [[sleep resistance]]; they are resistant to piercing and bludgeoning weapons, they have a roughly {{frac|2}} chance of reviving from their corpse, and their base dice for melee attacks are doubled (or tripled at [[midnight]]). However, they have a 2-point penalty to [[AC]] and take double damage from slashing weapons - weapons that have been given the "true death" boon by [[the Silver Flame]] deal double damage + 2d7 additional damage.<ref>Specifically, a bonus equal to double the sum of the base dice plus its enchantment, e.g. a +7 saber (1d8 base damage versus all monsters) would do 2x(1d8+7)+2d7.</ref> They also tend to move slower than living monsters: a monster with a [[speed]] of 6 or higher in their living form will have their speed in zombie form lowered to the higher of two values between half their normal speed and 6.

Other non-undead monsters will mutually [[grudge]] zombies, with each attacking the other on sight.

==Other zombies==
A basic [[Zombie (monster)#dNetHack|"zombie"]] still exists in monst.c as a form of fallback for [[wizard mode]], and is equivalent to the vanilla [[human zombie]] in this regard: [[Guard]]s, [[high priest]]s, [[aligned priest]]s, [[shopkeeper]]s, and [[Angel]]s are special-cased to become zombies if the player attempts to directly create them in [[wizard mode]], as is the case for them in vanilla ''[[NetHack]]'' - these monsters are not intended to be created outside of specific circumstances.{{refsrc|src/read.c|2415|version=NetHack 3.6.7|comment=In ''NetHack'', this applies to animating their corpse or statue as well. While this technically also applies to shopkeepers, revival is special-cased to work on them.}} <!--Commented pending visual confirmation: Unlike ''NetHack'', it is possible to properly animate the corpses and statues of these monsters (with the exception of temple priest corpses).-->

In addition to the above, dNetHack also has several distinct monsters in the [[Zombie (monster class)|zombie]] [[monster class]], most of them new: 

* {{brown|Z}} [[undead knight]]
* {{yellow|Z}} [[warrior of sunlight]]
* {{gray|Z}} [[undead maiden]]
* {{white|Z}} [[knight of the princess's guard]]
* {{brightblue|Z}} [[blue sentinel]]
* {{blue|Z}} [[darkmoon knight]]
* {{gray|Z}} [[undead rebel]]
* {{black|Z}} [[pardoner]]
* {{black|Z}} [[occultist]]
* {{black|Z}} [[ghoul]]
* {{black|Z}} [[hedrow zombie]]
* {{white|Z}} [[skeletal pirate]]
* {{yellow|Z}} [[hungry dead]]
* {{white|Z}} [[skeleton]]
* {{black|Z}} [[gnoll ghoul]]
* {{monsymlink|dread seraph}}
* {{brown|Z}} [[phalanx]]
